Safdarjung's tomb, model for Taj Mahal

Verso: A scene from "Romantic India," the Lowell Thomas film production which shows most of the beauty spots of Hindustan, glimpse of the life of the many races who live there, and all that is weird and wonderful in the strangest country in the world. One million people appear in this film production, scores of elephants, tigers, fakirs, and many weird sights
Alai Darwaza Gate to Qutub Minar

Idol of sacred cow, Well of Knowledge
Verso: The idol of the golden bull at Benares, one of the most famous places of worship in India. Lowell Thomas Travelogues

Verso: Benares, river scene Mosque reflection. The simple monotheistic minarets of Islam ride above the jumbled chaos of the hundreds of weird Hindu temples of Benares just as the simplicity of Muhammad's creed stands in striking contrast to the bewildering complexity of Hinduism

Lowell Thomas, Francis Yeats-Brown, Cape Comorin [2 copies]
Verso: Looking out over an unbroken expanse of sea from India to the South Pole
Lowell Thomas, Francis Yeats-Brown, Cape Comorin
Note: L.T. standing on a rock at the southernmost tip of the vast peninsula of Hindustan. This rock is called Cape Comoran. Very few travelers have been to this spot
Note: Hindu temples near the extreme southern tip of India
Verso: One black and one white
Two Brahmin priests, palm umbrellas [2 copies]

Verso: Two Brahmin priests in Southern India. The Brahmins consider themselves to be half man and half god. They are at the top of the Hindu caste system. The penalty for sitting down beside a Brahmin is to have the sitting part removed and to strike a Brahmin is to incur thousand years of hell. If the shadow of a European or a low caste Indian falls across the food of a Brahmin he must throw it away because it is defiled
Verso: The two boys are darker skinned than the old man who is as white as an European old man
Verso: A Malabar Knut one of the "mild" Hindoos of the West Coast whom the Moplalis failed to convert. A Hindu of the Malabar Coast
Boy with caste mark and big teeth
Youth, large caste marks on body
Man with big turban, caste mark and scraggly beard [2 copies]
Verso: Follower of Vishnu with the trident on his forehead. Between the two white prongs is a thin red one which is not distinguishable in the picture, Copyright by Lowell Thomas
Man with bushy hair and wide horizontal caste marks
Verso: Bullock carts and pilgrims in the bed of the river on the outskirts of Madura. In the distance looms the great temple
Lowell Thomas and Francis Yeats-Brown standing under banyan tree

Note: L.T. and Major Yeats Brown standing beneath a small portion of the famous Calcutta banyan tree, said to be the largest tree in the world. All of the verdure to be seen in this picture is a part of the one tree, and not more than a tenth of it is visible from this angle.
One tower of temple and street
Trichinopoly rock and water tank without pavilion
Temple gate, women with backs to camera
Tanjore temple, Lowell Thomas and other man in foreground [2 copies]
Note: L.T. standing in the courtyard of the Great Temple in Madura, one of the wonders of Asia
Verso: Light grey stone with red stripes running up and down part of it
Note: Hindu women, in southern India, praying for children, in front of phallic shrine
Verso: Jars are bright brick red. Building of slightly reddish sandstone but much of it dark grey from age
Verso: Ayannar - the god who rides by night - Make up and down cut of 3 principal figures
Two Pondicherry gods, young person in foreground
Verso: White statues with bright red, blue, and green eyebrows, hair, mustache, etc.

Note: the primitive device for raising water from a well to an irrigation ditch. The native holding the pole near the right of the picture, fills the bucket. The men on the teetering beam walk up and down in a way that raises the bucket to the height of the irrigation ditch. They walk up and down like this day in and day out, in the broiling sun, and receive for their labor the handsome honorarium of two cents a day
Note: A temple attendant. This man walks in front of the god, driving away the flies from the holy face by waving a Sacred Cow's tail. His matted hair is dressed with Holy Cow manure
Jagannath Temple, two Jagannath (Juggernaut) cars, great crowd of people
One Jagannath (Juggernaut) car on the move, very near view
Verso: The world-famous car of Juggernaut. Once each year the god, Juggernaut, most widely known of all Hindu idols, is placed in this car and taken for a ride

Note: The car of Juggernaut in the midst of its journey. Here are about five hundred thousand people taking part in the event. They all attempt to get hold of the ropes in order to pull the car. The Hindus call Juggernaut "God of the World"
Black Pagoda, Lowell Thomas in palki
Sun god standing, woman kneeling at feet
Lowell Thomas, two people of the Criminal Tribes, hut
Hut and family of the people of the Criminal Tribes
Chief of the people of the Criminal Tribes, full length
Verso: Man almost as black as a negro

Note: Chief Ankatigadu, known as "the man who stole six policemen," because he captures six native cops, disrobed them, put their uniforms on himself and companions, and then went up and down the country, robbing more than ever
Black Hole monument, Lowell Thomas in distance

Note: This iron fence encloses the spot famous in history as "the Black Hole of Calcutta." The palace of an Indian prince stood here long years ago. In it was a room the exact size of this enclosure, in which the Rajah imprisoned nearly two hundred Europeans. When the door was opened the next morning most of them were dead from suffocation. That tragedy led to one of the ten decisive battles in the history of the world, the Battle of Plassey, where Clive overthrew the Moghul emperor
Verso: Three instructors at Rabindrinath Tagor's school. The bearded gentleman on the left is a Frenchman from the Sorbonne
Abanindranath Tagore and Gaganendranath Tagore in garden
Dwijendranath Tagore, eldest of Tagore brothers, close-up
Lowell Thomas and other man reading in a train sleeper compartment
Lama with distorted face, nearer view
Lama with prayer wheel sitting on rock
Lama holding prayer wheel and staff, dagger in belt
River steamer, two small boats in foreground
Boat, sail up, two men poling
Man with grey beard, long hair on chest
Taj Mahal, with minarets, through doorway
Taj Mahal, four minarets, man on left [3 copies]
Verso: The finest tribute that was ever paid by man to the memory of woman, the sight that men journey all the way across the world to see, the most beautiful building on earth, the Taj Mahal
Taj Mahal through doorway, four minarets, man in foreground
Taj Mahal from balcony of gate, clouds
Taj Mahal from balcony of gate, slightly side view
Taj Mahal from balcony, quite a few people.
Taj Mahal from balcony, fine clouds
Taj Mahal from balcony, fine clouds
Taj Mahal, lilies and man, reflection in pool [2 copies]
Taj Mahal, side view, three minarets, clouds
Inside Agra Fort, Taj Mahal in distance
Taj Mahal in distance, columns and man in foreground
Jasmine tower through pillars, jasmine tower in distance.

Note: Akbar the Great, the leading Moghul ruler of India, many centuries ago, used this terrace to play a game of parchesi, using beautiful slave girls as the playing pieces. The Emperor and some noble of his court would sit on the raised dais, where L.T. is sitting. The Emperor and his companion would play the game in a way that would result in either one or the other winning most of the beautiful girls
Carved pillar, Sheikh Shisti smelling flowers
Building where Akbar held religious discussions
Old Sadhu with turban made of three rows of beads [2 copies]
Verso: An ash-smeared mendicant who watched the arrival of the World Fliers at Allahabad on the banks of the sacred Ganges
Two Sadhus close-up, pyramid shaped caste marks on foreheads
Sadhu with very small loin cloth
Hanuman the monkey god and a Sadhu
Verso: The Hindu Monkey God Hanuman.
Sadhu who raised dead, squatting, close-up
Sadhu who raised dead surrounded by disciples

Note: L.T. attending an afternoon session at which a famous Hindu Holy Man is instructing his followers in some of the secrets of oriental mysticism. The Holy Man, with the beard, claims to have the power of bringing animals back to life after they are dead, and his followers claim that he does all kind of other miracles.
Two Sadhus sitting on bed of spikes
Sadhu squatting under palm leaf shelter
Sadhu with white around eyes and rakish turban
Sadhu with big rock on stomach, close-up
Verso: Sadhu with rock on stomach
Deformed man on little cart, front view
Sadhu with deformed hands and feet
Two Sadhus covered with garlands of flowers and papers
Sadhu carrying sticks under arm and dish on head
Four men with sacred white bull
Hindu girl with nose bangles and hands on breast
Woman with swollen foot and toes, close-up of foot
Note: L.T. supervising filming of a scene, in India
Verso: Hindu woman with deformed legs. India
Verso: A British outpost on the Afghan frontier, the world's navel of bedevilment
Verso: Every British aviator wears this ransom letter sewn in his flying jacket. It tells the tribesmen they will receive a reward of $3000 if they bring the airman in safely
Young man with moustache wearing turban, smiling
Verso: Afghan bandits waiting to waylay a caravan.
Afridi house, Francis Yeats-Brown and crowd
Two dead men and automobile, close-up, showing wheels
Verso: Pictures of a raid on the Indian frontier. The wild tribesmen who inhabit the hills between India and Afghanistan are the most bloodthirsty brigands on earth
Verso: A mail car waylaid by brigands on the Indo-Afghan frontier
Verso: An Afghan feudist taking a pot shot at a neighbor
Trafalgar Square, Lundi Kotal, Lowell Thomas with foot on running board of automobile

Note: L.T. and party passing through the barbed wire barricade that marks the boundary between India and Afghanistan, at the western end of the famous Khyber Pass, the most strongly fortified mountain gorge in the world. Any one crossing this border without the consent of the Afghan King is almost certain to have his throat cut, in the name of Allah
Buick automobile in sand, Lowell Thomas
Buick automobile in front of tower fort
Note: L.T. and party at a roadside fort in the wild country of Afghanistan.
Soldier stopping automobile near frontier, Lowell Thomas at right
Note: L.T. being held up by frontier patrols at the border between India and Afghanistan
Verso: Pathan women on their way to Peshawar.
Verso: The spirit of 1930 in the Land of the Hindu Kush a Pathan dance
Old man on donkey, dog and man walking
Verso: An Afghan patriarch on his Rolls Royce
Cobbler with man squatting on each side of him
Scraggly patriarch, one hand on shoulder
One man wearing black turban, one wearing turban like flying helmet
Verso: Mendicants along the "golden road" across Afghanistan which leads from Peshawar to Samarkand.
Afghan sitting, smoking hookah, big white turban
Verso: A typical Afghan of Kabul enjoying a smoke in the caravanserai at Peshawar
Jalalabad Gate, Lowell Thomas driving automobile, talking to old man with donkey
Note: Contrast in transportation, at one of the gates of the Walled City of Jalalabad, in Afghanistan. L.T. at the wheel
Note: L.T. and party on the left, at the King's Palace, in Jalalabad
Panorama of Kabul, four men in foreground
Note: L.T. and party on one of the barren hills just above the city of Kabul, capital of the little-known country of Afghanistan.
Note: A picture made by L.T. from the walls of the Great Mosque in Kabul, the Afghan capital
Harry Chase, Lowell Thomas and Amir in automobile, Kabul [3 copies]

Note: L.T. and party in the city of Kabul. They are wearing the Afghan headdress, the so-called Afghan tarbush, made of Persian lamb. They did this at the request of the Amir of Afghanistan so that they would look as much like young Turks as possible. Christians are not welcome in the land of the Afghans
Verso: Lowell Thomas at the court of the Amir of Afghanistan in a forbidden part of central Asia.
Mohammed Dali Khan (Afghan minister for foreign affairs) and four high representatives in full dress
Verso: The Bolshevik envoy and wife in Kabul
Mohammed Dali Khan (Afghan minister for foreign affairs) in full dress
Verso: Mohammed Wali Khan, one of Amanullah's chief nobles who assisted him in his fight to regain his throne
Mohammed Dali Khan (Afghan minister for foreign affairs) in full dress

Verso: Afghanistan-No.59; Vali Muhammad Khan, Afghan Minister for Foreign Affairs. Although the Amir has never been out of his country, this member of his cabinet has recently returned from a world tour. Among other countries he visited the United States hoping to be able to get the President to send a permanent diplomatic official to the Amir's capital. Although Afghanistan has long been a forbidden land the new ruler is so anxious that his country shall play a prominent part in world affairs that he is inviting foreign powers to send ministers. It is rumoured the Afghan minister for Foreign Affairs considered he was shabbily treated in Washington because he was not officially recognized, although finally did meet President Harding and Secretary of State Hughes, informally. But America has not decided to send a diplomatic officer to the Amir's court. Nevertheless the American Charge d'Affairs at the Court of the Shah of Persia was asked to find out all he could about Afghanistan and make a report. It was through him that Mr. Lowell Thomas was at last successful in his wish to penetrate into the land of the Afghans. -He is acting as King in the Amir's absence at present!
Amir and three companions in tennis costumes sitting on bench [2 copies]
Verso: Left to right, The Amir, Field Marshal Shah Wali Khan, and two Afghan cabinet ministers. The men around the Amir are keen sportsmen like himself
Two lamp posts, rookery, high mountains
Note: L.T. Standing in the foreground with a cane under his arm, looking up at one of the mountains of Afghanistan
Abdul Rachman's palace at sunset, from vineyard
Verso: One of the Amir's palaces in Kabul now in the hands of wild Shinwari tribesmen
Friend of Amir standing under wooden arch
Lowell Thomas talking to Amir and brothers with back turned

Note: L.T. with back to the camera, being welcomed by the Amir of the Afghans, in the city of Kabu. The Amir is in the center of the group, wearing the riding boots. The heavyset gentleman in the white turban and robe, is his brother, who succeeded him as King
Amir after tennis match, standing [man at left cropped out]
Verso: Amanullah as a tennis player. His subjects objected to all of his western ideas
Amir's two daughters with little deer
Verso: Amanullah Khan and daughters, and pet deer
Amir's two daughters with little deer
Verso: The Amir and his two daughter[s] with their pet deer
Amir on horse coming out of palace gate
Verso: The Amir rides forth to the mosque; 9-1001
Verso: An Afghan colonel of cavalry
General on horse and Lowell Thomas
Note: L.T. and Shaw Wali Khan, Commander-in-Chief of the Afghan army, at a special review of military forces of Afghanistan, held outside the city of Kabul, in honor of L.T.
General standing by horse's head, Afghanistan
Verso: Afghan infantrymen. These are Kafirs, descendents of the army of Alexander the Great. They are neighbors of the Afridi's and live in the mountains northwest of Peshawar
Note: L.T. journeying in a most unromantic motortruck on his way to the most romantic place in the world, the beautiful Vale of Kashmir
Note: A picture of the Jelum River, on the way to the Vale of Kashmir
